body: Yeah, I think the idea was to merge this first, but the other PR also got finished around the same time and takes advantage of this extraction

The version in the other PR is more flexible. It allows creating JARs for any class meant to be used by the service loader. It also doesn't create the JAR for you each test. You have to call `createJarFor` explicitly. This was done because some tests in the test class don't need the JAR.
Oh I looked at the wrong PR was looking at #3829

> * Micrometer gauges do not accumulate values. They only fetch values from some source.

So is the point of this change the this "region perf stats" is the source of authority for the count of items in the region? This doesn't feel like the correct place for this. Shouldn't the region know its current size? Why is it being tracked externally?

> * We didn't want to invent a new meter type for this use caseâ€¦ yet. We may revisit this decision in the future as we get more experience linking Geode gauges to Micrometer gauges. (If we did create a new "cumulative gauge" meter type, that would also be "yet another thing.")

I see, its a mismatch between our stats definition of gauge and Micrometer's definition. 

> * We didn't want to configure the meter to fetch from the stat, because that would increase our dependence on stats. Given that we want to deprecate/remove stats eventually, we would eventually have to create some non-stat place to accumulate the increments and decrements. We chose to do that work now instead of deferring it until later.

Understandable in this gauge case, though I think we need to consider locality and ownership of these gauges. Where you are putting this feels like just another form of stats.

> * So we added a new field to accumulate the increments and decrements, and configured the meter and the stat to get their values from that.

Regions are just `Map` implementations right? `Map` has a `size` method. Shouldn't the gauges just be polling that method?

> Regions are just Map implementations right? Map has a size method. Shouldn't the gauges just be polling that method?

@pivotal-jbarrett PartitionedRegion.size() sends out messages to all the servers hosting buckets for that Region: `LocalRegion.size() -> LocalRegion.entryCount() -> LocalRegionDataView.entryCount(LocalRegion) -> PartitionedRegion.getRegionSize -> PartitionedRegion.entryCount(null) -> PartitionedRegion.entryCount(null, false) -> PartitionedRegion.getSizeRemotely(...) -> SizeMessage`

I didn't think it was a good idea to point the gauge at something that involves messaging. We could avoid adding the gauge for a PR and just add it for a non-PR regions (including BucketRegions). Unfortunately, non-PR regions have `synchronized` in the codepath for `LocalRegion.size()` which also seems like a bad idea for a meter.

I'm not against polling the stat itself. However, others didn't want to point the gauge at the stats since we are supposed to eventually delete the stats and be left with just meters.

> > We didn't want to configure the meter to fetch from the stat, because that would increase our dependence on stats. Given that we want to deprecate/remove stats eventually, we would eventually have to create some non-stat place to accumulate the increments and decrements. We chose to do that work now instead of deferring it until later.

> 
> Understandable in this gauge case, though I think we need to consider locality and ownership of these gauges. Where you are putting this feels like just another form of stats.

@pivotal-jbarrett We already tried to add meters outside the stats classes, but there were more people against that than one person (you) against us adding the meters in the stats classes.

> > * We didn't want to configure the meter to fetch from the stat, because that would increase our dependence on stats. Given that we want to deprecate/remove stats eventually, we would eventually have to create some non-stat place to accumulate the increments and decrements. We chose to do that work now instead of deferring it until later.
> 
> Understandable in this gauge case, though I think we need to consider locality and ownership of these gauges. Where you are putting this feels like just another form of stats.

It is. In general, I would prefer to connect each gauge to an existing source of reliable information, rather than relying on an instrumentation class to store the information. In this case, I would love to get the information from the region. But currently we don't know of an inexpensive, reliable source other than the `RegionPerfStats` class.

Do you know of a reliable source of entry counts that we can connect the meter and stat to? Barring that, can you think of a better place than `RegionPerfStats` to accumulate the increments and decrements?

> So is the point of this change the this "region perf stats" is the source of authority for the count of items in the region?

The source of authority was `Statistics`. We have moved the source of authority from there to the instrumentation class.

> This doesn't feel like the correct place for this.

Indeed. Is there an existing place that feels correct? If not, does the instrumentation class seem like a better place or worse place than the `Statistics` managed by the instrumentation class?

This pull request **fixes 1 alert** when merging b615d796e22820ba14d5adadf827663b1727a6f8 into 8718171b749552709876fa3f5cd74cdc1851941c - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-e77160e2719ea1402f77807dd7636e966d71714a)

**fixed alerts:**

* 1 for Equals method does not inspect argument type

> Do you know of a reliable source of entry counts that we can connect the meter and stat to? Barring that, can you think of a better place than `RegionPerfStats` to accumulate the increments and decrements?

That's exactly why I am asking. We have either created another ephemeral accounting class or a redundant external state class and both smell bad to me. 

My question about `Map.size` in this really, why isn't that method returning the exact same results of this `LongAdder`? If it does then why not embed this `LongAdder` in the various region classes and update `Map.size` to return the contents of the `LongAdder`. If this new value is meant to reflect the current state of the region but it is being updated outside the region how are we keeping this state in sync, and if the state is in sync why do we need two things holding this state?
If the value is ephemeral, like stats themselves, and there really is no better place to put this sort of thing, then cool.

This pull request **fixes 1 alert** when merging 5ae8fab2eec23fe1acf4a0b49758f3636da5a6b2 into f54e0ded1e1e4a8b29203d46f278cf293db6459d - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-1bc2160fca8400f544a0656e56f5de169039e97c)

**fixed alerts:**

* 1 for Equals method does not inspect argument type

> My question about `Map.size` in this really, why isn't that method returning the exact same results of this `LongAdder`? If it does then why not embed this `LongAdder` in the various region classes and update `Map.size` to return the contents of the `LongAdder`. If this new value is meant to reflect the current state of the region but it is being updated outside the region how are we keeping this state in sync, and if the state is in sync why do we need two things holding this state?
> If the value is ephemeral, like stats themselves, and there really is no better place to put this sort of thing, then cool.

I haven't found a better place yet.

CachePerfStats.incEntryCount(delta) is called from four places:

- `AbstractRegionMap.incEntryCount(delta)` increments if the map has an "owner" local region.
- `LocalRegion.incTombstoneCount(delta)` decrements the entry count by delta.
- `AbstractRegionEntry.makeTombstone(â€¦)` increments if the entry is new (to offset the decrement that happened when the entry was marked as a tombstone).
- `RegionMapPut.updateSize()` increments if the entry is not a tombstone and not an update.

I can't say what percentage of calls come through each of these methods. But three of the methods are not in any subclass of `Region`, so if we put the adder in the `Region` classes, we would have to add a method specifically to update this count, which is currently used only to report metrics.

After a bit of research (not by any means exhaustive) I can't find a `size()` method that gives a simple answer.

LocalRegion overrides Map.size() to call getDateView().entryCount(this). Each data view class computes the answer differently. And for any given data view class, the entryCount() method gives different answers depending on various conditions.

I have explored only a few of the implementations so far, but I have not yet found a case where the answer is is the same as the unadjusted result of calling Map.size().
We are investigating sources of "entry count" that are more direct and more reliable.

> We are investigating sources of "entry count" that are more direct and more reliable.

I am going to remove my block on this PR. I hope y'all can find a more direct method for getting the current size but if not then this approach is good too.

This pull request **fixes 1 alert** when merging 669480cf4db7fe778ec95267c45cda7d3f5d9995 into 64b277f3e71b781d0139fffc0d5db865ba0df261 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-3760b538c44aa163c525c550378f25a7b75530f4)

I have run full performance tests on this branch wrt develop and it passes with minor +/- variations that seem to be in line with what I see in the CI runs.
Failed test is a result of known issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-7005.

@dhemery I think the place to focus is `CustomEntryConcurrentHashMap::size`. It will attempt to get the count without locking but under update contention will resort to locking all the segments. I have a branch with some JMH benchmarks for this class already. If you want I can share and you can add one for calling size on an interval and see how that impacts puts.

@dhemery I made a small modification to the JMH I already had for comparing performance of `CustomEntryConcurrentHashMap`. I created a background thread that called `size` at 0ms (disabled, 1ms and 1s intervals. The benchmark used 100 threads to put or get concurrently into the maps. The `size` call had no measurable effect on the the put or get performance of `CustomEntryConcurrentHashMap`, which tops out on my machine 30M puts/s and 30M gets/s. It also shows no measurable performance impact on `ConcurrentHashMap`. So baring any serious locking going on at the `RegionBucket` down to the `CustomEntryConcurrentHashMap` you all should be good to go.

@jmelchio

I tried to make a fix for this and found some problems. Following the logic from _put, get_ and _putAll_ I made changes and see that in the case if user cannot get first entry from list exception will be thrown and go out from for loop and not try to get other entries(not a logic for _getAll_). How it works now, it logs all exceptions with the stacktrace but not throw it, so in logs we can see what entries user cannot get. 

So the solution is to throw exception when it first time occured and go out(same as putAll).

I modified PartitionedRegionCompactRangeIndexDUnitTest locally to see if I could repro the issue.  It looks like this occurs if the current value in the cache is already a tombstone and the new value also happens to be a tombstone.  I think this change should be fine, although I am wondering if we could no-op it instead to save from having to crawl through the index.

If the server being started has to recover really laaaarge disk stores and create indexes how will that affect the gfsh shell?  Will the user input be blocked until timeout or the disk stores are recovered?  Just curious what asynchronous startup tasks are affected by this change.

> If the server being started has to recover really laaaarge disk stores and create indexes how will that affect the gfsh shell? Will the user input be blocked until timeout or the disk stores are recovered? Just curious what asynchronous startup tasks are affected by this change.

Specifically, the two asynchronous startup tasks it's waiting on are redundancy recovery and disk store recovery. At the moment it will wait indefinitely for these two startup tasks.

It shouldn't hang waiting, but rather it should indicate what is happening.



--
Mike Stolz
Principal Engineer, Pivotal Cloud Cache

@mstolz1 @metatype Note, `start server` already hangs indefinitely waiting for the process to startup unless the process goes away. We just added two more tasks to the list of things that it waits on: redundancy recovery and recovery of persistent values (keys are already synchronous).

Changing the apparent interactiveness of GFSH during `start server` would require some changes to GFSH infrastructure which might be something this team shouldn't tackle (we could be looking at weeks of work for this). We should discuss in person.
Please review @kirklund @moleske @demery-pivotal @mhansonp

This was the intended commit message but the github merge hiccupped:

ServerLauncher start will now wait until all asynchronous startup tasks
complete to update server status as "online".

Previously, the server status was set to "online" before all of the
startup tasks had completed. This provided users with incorrect facts
about the system and its availability. This commit changes the behavior
of ServerLauncher.start() so that it waits for all of the asynchronous
startup tasks to complete before returning the "online" status. The GFSH
"start server" command relies on this status, so this also has the
effect of making the command wait for all startup tasks to complete
before returning.

* ServerLauncher.start() waits for startup tasks to complete
* Improve testability of ServerLauncher
* Extract ControllableProcess interface
* Change InternalResourceManager support for asynchronous startup tasks
* Move the responsibility for chaining the completion and exception
actions of startup tasks to ServerLauncher

Co-authored-by: Aaron Lindsey <alindsey@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Kirk Lund <klund@apache.org>
Co-authored-by: Dale Emery <demery@pivotal.io>
Note: @rhoughton-pivot has given me the go-ahead to commit this PR as is.

Thanks @jdeppe-pivotal,
I've changed the test to be more simple in my last commit, instead of multiple `key stores` and `trust stores` with/without the `CA` certificate there's now one single certificate in the `trust store` and multiple keys with aliases in the `key store`, which allows us to specifically test the correct usage of the the configured `alias` when obtaining the key. I'll merge the changes later today.
UnitTestOpenJDK11 hit the timeout exceeded problem that is under discussion on dev-list. Note that UnitTestOpenJDK8 passed.

Most of the other jobs allow 10 or 15 minutes between dumping stacks and the hard timeout.  There may be other housekeeping that eats into that buffer, I don't really know for sure, but to be on the safe side I would suggest dump stacks at 20m and timeout at 30m
I'd personally be fine with a 30 minute timeout and 20 minute dump stacks...if nobody opposes I'll go ahead and do that.

Merging as this code has been approved by two people with no requests for change.

The execute method returns a `ResultCollector`. `ResultCollector` does  have a timeout - there is `get(long, TimeUnit)` method. So naively, these new timeout parameters seem redundant.

The problem is that the `execute` method doesn't behave consistently when invoked on a peer vs. on a client. `execute` invoked on a peer doesn't block. It returns immediately, and the `ResultCollector` is how you wait for results. I think that's what you are seeing when you said your new parameters have no effect on `DistributedRegionFunctionExecutor`, etc.

I have seen in the past that invoking execute on a client *does* block, so I can see why you want to add these parameters to that method. Of course that means that the parameters to `ResultCollector.get` make no sense on the client (with or without these changes).

Maybe it would make more sense to make the `execute` on the client behave like it does when invoked on a peer - don't block, but return a result collector that can be used to wait for the results?

Hi @jinmeiliao, thank you for a help. 
I tested it, and it works great. We can close previous PR #3811
New PR is created. #3903

@upthewaterspout It makes a lot of sense to make the execute method non blocking and leave the blocking to the result collector together with the timeout. As a matter of fact, I found a ticket written by you a couple of years ago in which you already talked about this although it seems nobody has worked on it (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-3817).
Nevertheless, I currently see some problems with that approach:
- The C++ and C# clients already provide a timeout parameter in the execute methods and they are also blocking so in order to be consistent we would also have to change these two clients.
- In the Java client, as of today, when an execute call times out (because the execution takes longer than what is configured in the gemfire.CLIENT_FUNCTION_TIMEOUT property) after the configured retries have been reached, the connection is closed. We would lose this feature if we change the execute methods to be non-blocking.
- The current DefaultResultCollector ignores the timeout passed in the get method. It would be needed to implement the timeout handling in this method as well as in any custom collector. This is actually not a problem, just a finding.
As I am quite new in the community, I do not know how to progress with this PR. Should we go on with the changes proposed in this PR and at the same time start a discussion in the list about changing the execute methods to be non-blocking?

@kirklund It looks like this new module will export two root packages, o.a.g.alerting and o.a.g.logging. As we move towards Java 9 modules we need to make sure that jars have unique package exports. Can you verify that geode-core will no longer exports these two packages? Would it make sense to move o.a.g.alerting to o.a.g.loggging.alerting so that this module only exports a single root package? See `geode-cq`gradle for adding module information to the jar. 

Also if the use of log4j is an implementation detail, and the root package is o.a.g.logging, then perhaps this module should be 'geode-logging` and not `geode-log4j`?
I believe @balesh2 got access to update the wiki last week. I have it on my todo list to follow up with them.
@BenjaminPerryRoss
@kirklund @demery-pivotal @mhansonp

>   As I am quite new in the community, I do not know how to progress with this PR. Should we go on with the changes proposed in this PR and at the same time start a discussion in the list about changing the execute methods to be non-blocking?

I would lean towards resolving the the direction we want go with the API before merging this PR. It would unfortunate to introduce new API that introduces something we decide we don't want is immediately deprecated. Perhaps now would be a good time to close this PR, open a discussion on the dev@geode list with your ideas for normalizing the two clients, and then re-open this PR if it still makes sense after that discussion.
